alert.note: Alert for Escambia; Santa Rosa (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 16 at 3:38AM EDT until June 16 at 6:45AM EDT by NWS Mobile
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY FOR WEST PENSACOLA... The National Weather Service in Mobile has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... South Central Escambia County in northwestern Florida... Southwestern Santa Rosa County in northwestern Florida... * Until 545 AM CDT. * At 238 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated rounds of showers and thunderstorms continuing to train across Pensacola, West Pensacola, Warrington, Gulf Breeze, Myrtle Grove, and other nearby communities. Rainfall gauge reports indicate that between 8 and 15 inches of rain have fallen over the past several hours. An additional several inches of rainfall will be possible as storms continue to train across this area for the next one to three hours. Escambia County Emergency Management reports numerous high water rescues ongoing early this morning with several structures inundated with flooding. This is a FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY for West Pensacola. This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! HAZARD...Thunderstorms producing life threatening flash flooding. SOURCE...Gauges reported. IMPACT...This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! Life threatening flash flooding of low water crossings, small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Pensacola, West Pensacola, Warrington, Gulf Breeze, Goulding, Myrtle Grove, Brownsville and Beach Haven. FLASH FLOOD...GAUGE INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CATASTROPHIC EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...2-4 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Move to higher ground now! This is an extremely dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
